Problem:
Consider a system where the heat distribution \\( u(x, t) \\) in a rod is governed by the heat equation \\( u_t = k u_{xx} \\), with \\( k \\) being the thermal diffusivity constant. We explore how the Fourier transformation \\( F(u) \\) at time \\( t \\) and its modification by a function \\( g(x, t) = e^{-\alpha t} \\), where \\( \alpha \\) is a constant, affect the system.

Assuming the intervention \\( g(x, t) \\) is applied at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), will the Fourier transformed state \\( F(u) \\) at \\( t = T \\) for \\( T > t_1 \\) be solely dependent on the original heat equation parameters and independent of \\( \alpha \\)?
Explanation: The function \\( g(x, t) = e^{-\alpha t} \\) acts as a damping factor, influencing the heat distribution and thus the Fourier transform results. The intervention changes the system’s state post-\\( t_1 \\), making \\( F(u) \\) at \\( t = T \\) dependent not only on the heat equation but also significantly on \\( \alpha \\).

causal_map_integration: The evolution of the Fourier transform F(u) over time is influenced by the heat equation parameters but is modified by the function g(x, t) which introduces a time-dependent decay factor e^(-αt). After applying g(x, t) at time t1, F(u) at time T (T > t1) incorporates this decay effect from t1 to T.
